para.text: Dolphin Smalltalk runs a multiprocessing environment where one of the processes is dedicated to receiving user input. Most of the time, when you evaluate code in a
this will be executed on the user input thread. You can see this because, if you perform a time-consuming operation, the user interface will pause until it has completed.

Unfortunately, there's always the possibility that you may cause something to happen on the user interface process which either never terminates or at least takes a very long time to complete. This may be due to a programming error in the underlying code that you are executing or just a mistake in the code you are evaluating. The end result will be that Dolphin will appear to "lock up" and control will not return to the user interface.
In fact, in these circumstances, Dolphin hasn't "locked up" it is just executing in a very tight loop inside the virtual machine.
Fortunately, there is usually a way to break into such a loop and you can do this by typing

key press. If this is the case and you have typed
